In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation of or 
reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development Bank 
does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Malaysia  is  at  a  critical  juncture  in  its  development.  It  has  made  huge  strides  in 
socioeconomic  development  since  the  1970s,  transforming  itself  from  an  underdeveloped 
country reliant on natural resources into a middle-income country with a vibrant manufacturing 
sector. While Malaysia has made strong gains, the current situation poses some challenges that 
have led some to suggest that Malaysia is in a middle-income trap.  
 
2.  The government has been proactive in taking on these challenges. Specifically, it has 
issued a comprehensive policy framework through the Economic Transformation Programme 
(ETP)1 and the Tenth Malaysia Plan (TMP), 2011–2015,2 in recognition that a new economic 
model is required. In addition, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has formed an interim 
country  partnership  strategy  (CPS)  with  Malaysia  to  support  the  government  in  the 
implementation  of the ETP  and  the TMP.3 In this  context,  the government  has  requested 
technical assistance (TA). The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The key pillars for Malaysia during this rapid economic transformation, as envisioned by 
the government’s own policies and backed up by International Monetary Fund and ADB reports, 
include  (i)  economic  growth  that  is  led  by  the  private  sector;  (ii)  market  liberalization  to 
encourage trade and investment; and (iii) macroeconomic stability with its corresponding policy 
tools for inclusive growth. 5 The ratio of investment to Malaysia’s GDP has stagnated to below 
10% for more than a decade, compared with an average of more than 30% during the mid–
1990s. With the government’s fiscal deficit now projected to widen in 2011, the ETP envisages 
that investments will largely come from an increase in private capital or via public–private 
partnerships  (PPPs).  Direct  private  sector  investments  that  support  inclusive  growth  and 
promote an environment conducive to business will include ensuring Malaysia’s export financing 
is geared toward strengthening exporting activities. The need to support export financing from 
institutions like Eximbank is particularly important as export expansion moderated to 10.4% on a 
year-on-year basis in the third quarter from 26.2% in the first half of 2010. The downturn in major 
industrialized  economies  will  require  diversification  of  exports  and  promotion  of  trade  and 
investment with emerging and nontraditional markets. These initiatives for strengthening exports 
and regional market development will leverage on regional initiatives involving the Association 
of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines 
East  ASEAN  Growth  Area,  and  the  Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand  Growth  Triangle.  While 
Malaysia  has  been  successful  in  reducing  poverty,  some  population  segments  in  certain 
geographic locations remain at risk. In the TMP, attention will shift towards the bottom 40% of 
income households. As the economy undergoes structural transformation, macroeconomic tools 
to help evaluate the effects of government policy at the household level will be critical in 
assessing access to growth. 
 
4.  Based on the above, an interim CPS has been formulated with the objective of helping 
Malaysia get out of the middle-income trap through private sector development (including PPPs)

2   
and  regional  cooperation  and  integration  (RCI),  particularly  by  reinforcing  outward  and 
commercial orientation. To this end, the major development issues to be addressed by ADB are 
as follows: 
 
(i)  National anchoring of RCI. Anchoring RCI at the national level has the dual 
benefit  of  contributing  to  Malaysia’s  development  goals  and  supporting  the 
development of neighboring countries. The outward orientation inherent in this 
approach supports Malaysia’s efforts to emerge from the middle-income trap 
through more competitive and broader trade and investment opportunities.  
 
(ii)  Catalyzing  private  investment.  Malaysia’s  key  economic  challenge  is  to 
develop its private sector. By promoting a commercial orientation, development 
finance institutions (DFIs) can, for example, boost the ability of Malaysian private 
enterprises to take advantage of regional market opportunities. ADB can support 
projects that  catalyze  private  sector  participation,  including  PPPs,  to finance 
infrastructure.  
 
(iii)  Maximizing  knowledge  partnership.  The  government  aims  to  promote 
inclusive  growth.  Expanding  human  capital  development  and knowledge  and 
capacity development efforts will be important in this regard. In addition, as the 
economy goes through the structural transformation envisaged by the TMP and 
ETP, a macroeconomic tool to monitor the inclusive growth will be needed.  
 
The TA aims to support the government’s efforts in ensuring macroeconomic stability with 
inclusive growth and in enabling new engines of growth for an economy during a period of 
structural transformation. To help tackle these issues, knowledge and capacity development TA 
is required that can assist in (i) monitoring various aspects of inclusive growth during a period of 
structural  transformation,  (ii)  promoting  PPP-enabling  policy  and  regulatory  reforms  and 
financing, and (iii) encouraging outward-oriented private sector development based on vibrant 
export growth with effective export financing—which in turn will encourage partnership in global 
and regional production networks. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The  overall  impact  will  be  stronger  development  of  Malaysia  through  effective 
implementation of the TMP and ETP. This will be based on continued efforts for better outward 
and commercial orientation, leading to a more integrated region. Based on the interim CPS, the 
government  has  requested  ADB’s  assistance  via  provision  of  knowledge  and  capacity 
development. In particular, the consultation between the government and ADB has led to the 
identification of key strategic thrusts for the structural transformation of the economy and its 
impact (as envisioned in the TMP and ETP) to be supported by ADB. Specifically, and as stated 
in the TMP and ETP, the economic transformation of Malaysia is to be based on private sector 
development,  with  stronger  outward  and  commercial  orientation  of  key  institutions.  This 
transformation would need to be accompanied by inclusive growth for Malaysia.  
 
6.  The overall outcome of the TA is improved capacity of selected entities to implement 
TMP  and  ETP,  particularly  in  regard  to  the  following  three  key  strategic  priorities:  (i) 
development  of  macroeconomic  policy  tools  based  on  robust  databases  and  modeling  to 
measure the impact of structural transformation on inclusive growth in terms of household 
incomes; (ii) promotion of private sector development by catalyzing additional investments,

3 
which includes PPP financing opportunities and enabling policy and regulatory reforms; and (iii) 
support  for  stronger  commercial  and  outward  (export-driven)  orientation.  These  areas  are 
consistent with the government’s policy framework as noted above, and are considered key 
facets  of  economic  transformation  for  Malaysia.  While  the  TA  cannot  support  all  of  the 
government’s policies, it can have a catalytic impact with a tangible demonstration of ADB’s 
engagement. 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  To achieve the TA outcomes, the TA contains three components which are based on the 
strategic pillars of the interim CPS. They are designed to provide enhanced capacity and 
knowledge support in the key areas of the TMP and ETP implementation. Further description of 
the components is below.  
 
(i)  National anchoring of RCI (support for export financing). This component will 
target the Export-Import Bank of Malaysia (Eximbank Malaysia) and SME Bank. 
Based on the interim CPS, ADB will initiate a project financing development with 
Eximbank  Malaysia  to  strengthen  cross-border  and  regional  trade  and 
investment initiatives, and to support clean energy finance across the region. To 
ensure  that  ADB’s  financing  support  is  complemented  by  its  capacity 
development support, this TA component will focus on the areas of internal risk 
management and project risk analysis, as well as upgrading trade and clean 
energy finance to develop value-added services that foster regional trade and 
investment. In addition to its own outputs, the TA will arrange for a training 
program to be implemented with other export-import banks in the region.  
 
(ii)  Catalyzing private investment (support for PPP financing). The TA will help 
examine the constraints on PPPs with the target of improving the procedural and 
other administrative processes to catalyze additional private sector investments. 
It  is  important that  Malaysia’s  PPP  policies  and  procedural requirements  be 
closely  aligned  with  international  best  practice.  With  this,  the  TA  can  help 
pinpoint a potential pool of private and/or PPP-based projects that could be 
financed by private and international sources.  
 
(iii)  Maximizing  knowledge  partnership  (support  for  macroeconomic  policy). 
This  component  will  draw  from  and  complement  the  work  of  ADB  TA  for 
Strengthening  Planning  Capacity  for  Low-Carbon  Growth  in  Developing  Asia 
which was launched in 2010 to develop a computable general equilibrium (CGE) 
model concentrating on the economic impact of climate change.6 Building on 
similar assumptions, variables, and base data used in this CGE model, this TA 
will further improve the CGE model to estimate the impact of government policies 
and external shocks on different types of households in the Malaysian economy. 
The main activities include the provision of hands-on training to the modeling 
team and local counterparts on how to construct a social accounting matrix (SAM) 
based  on  a  CGE  model.  Various  capacity  development  and  dissemination 
activities  will  be  required,  including  participation  from  universities,  research 
institutes, etc.  
 
                                                
6  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Enabling Climate Change Responses in Asia and the Pacific–Strengthening 
Planning Capacity for Low Carbon Growth in Developing Asia (TA 7645 [Subproject 4], for $1,420,000, approved 
on 10 November).

4   
8.  Based on the above, the TA is designed to have three sets of outputs:  
 
(i)  The  export  financing  component  will  have  the  following  outputs:  (a) 
recommendations to improve internal risk management and project risk analysis 
of  DFIs,  and  on  rectifying  known  areas  of  operational  weaknesses  through 
institutional capacity building; (b) detailed training, workshops, and seminars as 
deemed appropriate; and (c) demonstrable improvement of staff's knowledge 
application in financial products and project life cycles, including guidance to 
respective advisory units.  
(ii)  The private and PPP financing component will have these technical outputs: 
(a) recommendations on enhanced PPP financing procedures to develop priority 
projects, including removal of potential constraints to international financing; and 
(b) identification of opportunities for PPP financing, including those related to 
social infrastructure such as vocational training.7  
 
(iii)  The macroeconomic policy component will have detailed technical outputs on the 
development of policy tools for effective macroeconomic management, including 
further development of a CGE model, which are interlinked and fine-tuned with 
other economic modules. This will also entail the preparation of training and 
documentation manuals, and conduct of training in the design of country-specific 
social policies (with the SAM and others) and instruments and key strategic 
scenarios based on linked and hybrid model analysis.  
 
These TA outputs are based on the strategic framework of engagement between ADB and the 
government as described above. They further represent areas of expertise and experience for 
ADB. In particular, as the TA is on a reimbursable basis, ADB needs to deliver high-quality 
outputs on a timely basis, with inputs from relevant departments. Accordingly, the outputs have 
been tailored to ensure effective delivery based on the TA’s duration and resource availability. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1 million equivalent. It is proposed that ADB will 
finance an estimated amount of $1 million from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-
Others) on reimbursable basis. Detailed procedure for reimbursement will be prepared as part 
of the overall TA agreement. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented from 15 February 2012 to 15 February 2013, and the 
Economic Planning Unit (EPU) will be the executing agency. The EPU will be responsible for 
overall coordination between the Malaysian institutions involved in the TA. On ADB's part, the 
Southeast  Asia  Department's  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations  Coordination  Division 
(SERC) will be the focal point. As ADB will need to provide its utmost knowledge and capacity 
development support under the TA, a number of divisions within the Southeast Asia Department 
and other ADB departments will work with the various implementing agencies: 
 
                                                
7  After the identification of potential projects, ADB and the relevant Malaysian institutions are expected to engage in 
further discussions on modalities of support on project structuring. Due to the high resource requirements for PPP 
project structuring, this TA is not expected to undertake the full range of activities.  The TA will identify an 
appropriate set of areas to be supported per each of the potential projects as a screening process, based on the 
government’s policy framework and ADB’s proposed PPP Operations Plan.

5 
(i)   For the economic modeling component, the implementing agency will be the 
EPU;  SERC  will  work  with  the  Economic  Research  Department  to  ensure 
coordination with its TA on CGE modeling8 . 
 
(ii)   For  the  DFI  component,  the  implementing  agency  will  be  the  Bank  Negara 
Malaysia (in coordination with the Ministry of Finance and relevant DFIs); SERC 
will coordinate with the Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division 
of the Southeast Asia Department.  
 
(iii)   For the PPP component, the implementing agencies will be the Performance 
Management Delivery Unit and the PPP Unit (UKAS) within the Prime Minister’s 
Office; SERC will coordinate with the other sector divisions in its department, and 
with ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department. Additional support can be 
given  by  ADB’s  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and 
community of practice on PPP.  
 
As noted above, this coordinated approach takes into account both the need to ensure effective 
implementation of the TA and the broad knowledge base available within ADB. 
 
11.   A group of individual consultants (and firms as appropriate9) will provide the advisory, 
technical, and administrative support services. In total, it is estimated that about 25 person-
months of international consulting services and about 50 person-months of national consulting 
services  are  required  for  the  TA’s  three  components.  Due  to  the  diverse  skills  required, 
consultants will be engaged on an individual basis (or through a firm for each of the three main 
components)  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). SERC staff will review the outputs in coordination with the relevant 
ADB departments.  The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
12.   Purchases  of  equipment  (computer  hardware  and  software)  will  be  undertaken  in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and in 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  the  Office  of 
Administrative Services, where applicable. After TA completion, any procured equipment will be 
disposed of in compliance with Project Administration Instruction 5.09. Disbursements under the 
project will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a reimbursable 
basis to the Government of Malaysia for Supporting the Tenth Malaysia Plan, 2011–2015, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  All consultants for the technical assistance (TA) project of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) in support of the Tenth Malaysia Plan, 2011–2015 will be recruited according to ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under the TA will be in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Consulting services may be provided intermittently, 
based on agreement between the consultants, the government agencies, and ADB.  
A.  Computable General Equilibrium Modeling Component  
2.  Computable  General  Equilibrium  (CGE)  modeling  specialist  (1  international,  7 
person-months). The consultant must have extensive knowledge of and hands-on experience in 
developing national dynamic CGE that is synchronized within a regional CGE model, along with 
detailed social accounting matrices (SAMs). Specifically, the consultant will:   
 
(i)  Examine and assess the SAM 2005 to be used as the basis for developing a 
CGE model for Malaysia's economy; 
(ii)  Examine any other data and methodologies in relation to this study that warrant 
consideration; 
(iii)  Develop static and dynamic versions of the CGE model representative of the 
economy.  The  model  should  incorporate  some  flexible  alternative  functional 
specifications so that the model can be used to deal with various issues specified 
by the government; 
(iv)  Provide hands-on training to the modeling team and local counterparts on how to 
construct a SAM, and develop, update, and run a CGE model. This capacity 
building is to ensure continuous maintenance and application of the model by the 
local counterparts. 
(v)  Establish  a  comprehensive  baseline  scenario  and  prepare  various  scenarios 
complying with the long-term projection to effect simulations such as: 
(a)  impacts of world economic development, cost reductions on prices, public 
sector and development expenditure, import tariff reduction following trade 
liberalization, bilateral trade agreement, and changes in export demand; 
(b)  effects of the capital market on the balance of payments, including foreign 
direct investment, short-term capital inflows, and exchange rate policy; 
(c)  effects of commodity prices on domestic prices; and 
(d)  effects  of  trade  policy  (bilateral  trade  agreements)  on  the  Malaysian 
economy. 
(vi)  Prepare a user's guide that includes the theoretical structure of the CGE model, 
its computer codes, and the detailed data sets used;  
(vii)  Present  the  findings  through  workshops  and/or  seminars  along  with  the 
consultants; and  
(viii)  Support the executing and implementing agencies and ADB in other activities 
relevant to the TA’s main scope.  
 
The consultant should have at least 15 years of experience in economic modeling, preferably in 
Asia; a degree in economics is preferred. 
 
B.  Development Finance Institutions, Risk, and Advisory Component 
3.  Credit  risk  management  specialist  (1  international,  4.5  person-months).  The 
consultant must have extensive knowledge of and hands-on experience in developing and

10  Appendix 3 
upgrading credit risk management systems in a range of credit and non-credit rated financial 
institutions. Specifically, the consultant will: 
(i)  Undertake the due diligence of up to two financial institutions and review the 
existing credit risk management system and supporting governance procedures, 
including guiding regulations issued by the Ministry of Finance, Bank Negara 
Malaysia, or the Securities and Exchange Commission, as relevant; 
(ii)  Review the classification of the following risk categories and provide technical 
capacity upgrading as may be required: (a) credit risk, (b) market risk, (c) liquidity 
risk, (d) operation risk, (e) legal risk, (f) reputation risk, (g) strategic risk, and (h) 
compliance risk; 
(iii)  Review the organizational and staff profile of the risk analysis department and 
provide  technical  capacity  upgrading  as may  be  required,  specifically  in  risk 
management, risk administration and risk modeling, and risk policy. Review the 
timelines for completing credit review proposals; and the structure of approval 
committees; 
(iv)  Review the regulations guiding the following: (a) the scope of risk management; 
(b) supervision; (c) risk management policies; (d) procedures and determination 
of  risk  limits;  (e)  risk  identification,  measurement,  monitoring,  and  control 
processes; (f) risk management information systems; (g) internal control systems; 
(h)  the  organization  and  function  of  risk  management;  (i)  risk  management 
committees, (j) the risk management unit, (k) new products, and (l) reporting and 
assessment. Indicate gaps and scope of upgrading, as may be required; 
(v)  Provide  assessment  on  the  key  issues  associated  with  nonperforming  loan 
recovery,  asset  management  functions,  and  product  development  and/or 
advisory  services  currently  provided  by  the  relevant  development  finance 
institutions;  
(vi)  Provide timelines and budget estimate for institutional, governance, information 
technology systems, and staff training, and for suggested additional skill inputs at 
the financial institution or government bank (by the time of the inception report 
delivery); 
(vii)  Undertake training as may be required, further to consultation with the target 
institution's senior management and in consultation and agreement with ADB, 
over the remainder of the consultancy, with periodic assessment and adjustment 
as may be required by senior management and in consultation with ADB; 
(viii)  Provide  inputs  and  support  on  the  logistics  for  the  training  program  to  be 
developed with other export-import banks in the region; and  
(ix)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
 
The  consultant should have  at  least  15  years  of  experience  in  risk management  /  export 
financing, preferably in Asia; a degree in finance is preferred. 
 
4.  Energy efficiency, renewable energy finance and advisory specialist (1 international, 
3 person-months). The consultant must have extensive knowledge of and hands-on experience 
in developing energy efficiency finance products for the commercial sectors, as well as a 
working knowledge of export credit, insurance, and guarantee products, and familiarity with 
Berne Union best practices in energy efficiency. In addition, the consultant will: 
(i)  Assist the department heads of the government bank(s) in their review of energy 
efficiency finance products and risk models, and explore cofinancing options 
such as the Clean Development Mechanism, as may be relevant;

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Coordinate with the international credit risk management expert to undertake 
stress testing of project models to verify risks and their impact on claims payment. 
Review the existing risk management model and assess its adequacy to ensure 
sustainability and profitability of business in energy efficiency and renewable 
energy.  Propose  appropriate  changes  for  adoption  by  the  bank  that  are  in 
keeping with Berne Union guidelines; 
(iii)  Provide hands-on training to broaden staff members’ knowledge and application 
of energy efficiency and renewable energy finance products, including advanced 
concepts in project finance; 
(iv)  Introduce to the advisory unit on-the-job training and guidance on marketing and 
promoting  energy  efficiency  finance  and  renewable  energy  products  to 
commercial banks and chambers of commerce; and  
(v)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
 
The consultant should have at least 15 years of experience in project financing, preferably in 
Asia; a degree in finance is preferred. 
 
5.  Credit risk management specialist (1 national, 4.5 person-months). The consultant 
must be a credit risk management practitioner and financial expert on small and medium-sized 
enterprise and corporate finance, and possibly project finance, and have a working knowledge 
of credit risk management. The consultant will: 
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  the  review  of  financial,  legal,  and  other  capacity-
building requirements in the DFIs; 
(ii)  Prepare all credit risk management training materials with the other TA team 
members and provide hands-on training; 
(iii)  Coordinate with management and staff of the government bank(s) as required to 
ensure effective implementation of the TA; and  
(iv)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
 
The consultant should have at least 5 years of experience in risk management, preferably in 
Malaysia; a degree in finance is preferred. 
 
6.  Clean energy finance and project finance specialist (1 national, 3 person-months). 
The consultant must be a project finance practitioner, and have an applied knowledge of clean 
energy finance products. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Assist the team leader with the review of financial, legal, and other capacity-
building requirements in the government bank(s), as required; 
(ii)  Prepare all relevant project finance and clean energy finance training materials 
and provide hands-on training along with the other TA team members; 
(iii)  Coordinate with DFIs’ management and staff as required to facilitate the smooth 
implementation of the TA; and  
(iv)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
 
The consultant should have at least 5 years of experience in project financing, preferably in 
Malaysia; a degree in finance is preferred.

12  Appendix 3 
7.  Technical Assistance coordinator and economist (1 national, 6 person-months). The 
economist will support ADB and the government agencies for the TA's overall outputs. The 
economist will also support ADB on various administration and logistical activities of the TA, 
including the necessary procurements for the TA. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
  
(i)  Assist the team members with the collation of data on financial, legal, and other 
capacity-building requirements of the TA, as required; 
(ii)  Develop an abbreviated communication plan to effectively disseminate 
information and coordinate between the relevant stakeholders;  
(iii)  Administer the costs of workshops and other relevant activities; 
(iv)  Provide administrative support to the inception, interim, and final reports, and 
regular post-workshop reports to ADB and the government; and  
(v)  Assist  in  liaising  with  the  government  and  ADB,  and  with  other  relevant 
stakeholders  (including  the  private  sector)  in  other  activities,  including 
administrative and logistical support relevant to the TA’s main scope. 
 
The consultant should have at least 5 years of experience in public policy/economics, preferably 
in Malaysia; a degree in economics or related fields is preferred. 
 
C.  Public–Private Partnership Project Development Component   
8.  Public–Private Partnership (PPP) specialist (1 international, 8 person-months). The 
consultant  should  be  cognizant  that  commitment  to  support  private  sector  participation  in 
infrastructure,  particularly  via  PPPs,  is  derived  from  ADB’s  long-term  strategic  framework, 
Strategy 2020, which reinforces the notion that for Malaysia, private expertise and finance offer 
better  possibilities  for  efficiency  gains  in  infrastructure  investment  and  in  management. 
Specifically, the tasks entail:   
(i)  Construct a design for comprehensive project identification and development 
mechanisms  for  the  ―entry  point  projects‖  (as  defined  in  the  government’s 
Economic  Transformation  Programme)  and  other  sources,  to  assess  their 
suitability for private and public financing, in close consultation with the relevant 
government agencies;  
(ii)  Identify priority projects for PPP and private financing—the projects should be 
closely aligned with the Tenth Malaysia Plan (including the ―entry point projects‖) 
based on relevant guidelines from the government and ADB;   
(iii)  Along  with  the  other  team  members,  conduct  an  analysis  on  the  market 
conditions relevant to the PPP and/or private investments, including the activities 
and experiences of the comparator entities or activities. This should be compared 
with  the  relevant  procedural  and  administrative  requirements  based  on 
international best practice, and also with the relevant guidelines of ADB;  
(iv)  Review  the  relevant  procedures  for  PPP  and/or  private  investments  and 
recommend improvements as appropriate; and  
(v)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
The consultant should have at least 15 years of experience in project financing, preferably in 
Asia; a degree in finance is preferred. 
 
9.  Team of project development mechanism specialists (3 national, 36 person-months 
total). The national consultants’ knowledge must extend to analyzing economic internal rates of

Appendix 3  13 
return  and  writing  evaluation  studies  to  inform  and  recommend  improvements  to  potential 
nonsovereign public and private projects, including PPP projects. The consultants will:  
(i)  Assist the international consultant in defining priority projects for PPP and/or 
private financing. The projects should be closely aligned with the government’s 
policy framework (including the ―entry point projects‖) and relevant ADB policies;   
(ii)  Support ADB staff members and government officials in dissemination activities, 
as required; and  
(iii)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
10.  Based on the above, the consultants will be  expected to produce a set of studies 
(i.e., potential project profiles) based on ADB guidelines. The consultants should have at least 
5 years of experience in project financing, preferably in Asia. 
 
11.  Private  sector  development  specialist  (1  international,  2  person-months).  The 
consultant must have proven and extensive experience in private sector and investment policy, 
and be broadly familiar with approaches and modalities of promoting PPPs, and regulatory 
framework and legislative reform in developing economies. The consultant will undertake the 
following tasks:  
(i)  Formulate a set of detailed recommendations for Malaysia with a focus on the 
PPP market, focusing on constraints in the regulatory framework, capital market, 
and project finance space in Malaysia; 
(ii)  Provide advice and undertake policy dialogue with high-level representatives of 
the  government  and  the  private  sector  regarding  the  relevant  issues,  as 
appropriate; and  
(iii)  Support the government and ADB in other activities relevant to the TA’s main 
scope.  
The  consultant  should  have  at  least  15  years  of  experience  in  PPP  and  private  sector 
development, preferably in Asia; a degree in economics is preferred. 
 
D.   Reporting Requirements 
12.  The consultants will submit the following reports for all three components to be adjusted 
based on the TA requirements: 
 
(i)  Inception report (1 month after the start of services), presenting the initial findings 
and  the work program, based on their terms of reference;  
(ii)  First  interim report  (3  months after  the  start  of  services),  presenting  the 
preliminary  findings  and  recommendations,  and  proposing  modifications,  if 
any, to the TA activities during the remaining period;  
(iii)  Second interim report (6 months after the start of services), presenting detailed 
findings and recommendations, particularly on the technical assessment of the 
three main topics, as outlined above; 
(iv)  Third interim report (9 months after the start of services), presenting detailed 
findings and recommendations, building the basis for the final report; and  
(v)  Draft final report (12 months after the start of services), describing in detail the 
work undertaken, and presenting the study conclusions and recommendations. 
The  final  report  will  be  submitted  consequently,  incorporating  all  relevant 
comments from the stakeholders.
